document.docAuthor: González, María E., Grismado, Cristian J. & Ramírez, Martín J.
document.masterDocTitle: A Taxonomic Revision Of The Spider Genus Meriola Banks (Araneae: Trachelidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A Taxonomic Revision Of The Spider Genus Meriola Banks (Araneae: Trachelidae)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Meriola teresita
Platnick & Ewing, 1995: 34
, figs 87–91 (male holotype and female allotype from Santa Teresita , Buenos Aires , Argentina , in MACN, examined).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. Both sexes resemble those of
M. ramirezi
by the orange-brown carapace and smooth cuticle, and uniform gray abdomen. Males ( Figs 84–85 ) can be distinguished by having leg cuspules, and by the RTA with two tiny tips. Females ( Fig. 83 ) can be distinguished by the large spherical S2 with stalks, and small spherical S1 and CDR ( Platnick & Ewing, 1995 : figs 90, 91).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 90 . Known distribution of
Meriola californica
,
M. cetiformis
and
M. decepta
in America. Records of
M. decepta
in South America marked with a dotted line are probably recent introductions.

subSubSection.paragraph: Description. Male and female described by Platnick & Ewing (1995) .

Natural history and habitat. The specimens were collected in leaf litter and at the base of
Cortaderia selloana
.
Distribution. Known from Rio Grande do Sul in Brazil , Canelones in Uruguay and Buenos Aires province in Argentina ( Fig. 92 ).

New records.
